It depends on too many things to give a specific answer here but
as a general rule I would always try to have my runtime release
code check for the 'cleanness' of all connections, even if I had
to write a specific class with functionality for this.
I'd then hammer these with unit test cases to make sure they will
always gurantee clean conncections.
I'm not very up on JDBC. You may have to wrap JDBC in your own
shell to provide the integrity checking.

Noboddy should need reminding that whatever it costs, a clean
database is worth the pain.

>For software quality two of the most important things to test for
>(if you can) are:
>1. Connections are 'clean' when you put them back in the pool.
>The next piece of code to use the connection should be able to
>do so without fear of picking up a bad connection or one which
>wasn't tidied up properly by the last user.

Just out of interest, (and getting a little OT) is there any way to check 
(within the code - not as a unit test) that the connection is "clean" - ie 
ResultSets, statements closed etc.?
